I was quite young when my children were born, around 25, and I found the responsibilities challenging. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I appreciate. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which helped me stay connected in my work. I missed some important moments, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on vacations to the south of France, and they enjoy spending time with our friends and attending parties and advertising events without feeling out of place. I think it helps that my job is seen as exciting.

**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as my political career grew, finding time became difficult. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if my children can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they don’t feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed more politicians bringing their children to work, which shows we are becoming more aware of the importance of including our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, which made me think more about fatherhood. I worked hard to stay connected with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while so they could visit easily, but I think that confused them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I wonder if I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my children like adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too lenient. I wish I had set more rules and structure. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as my youngest. In that way, your children never really leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for children. I was 30, had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new furniture?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. Creating a child feels very special, and it is. But it also makes you just one of many parents. It can be frustrating at times, but any irritation disappears with just one look at her. A baby's smile is incredibly powerful; it can melt anyone's heart.

**Text:**

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's ten-act play about a powerful warrior can feel long, but Terry Hands' production makes it one of the most exciting nights of the year. He has cut parts of the text and created a show that combines the beauty of Marlowe's writing with fast-paced action. Antony Sher shines in the title role, performing impressive stunts while delivering his lines, capturing the audience's full attention with his intense desire for power and glory. Great performance.  
Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, which was first shown at the Manchester Royal Exchange in May, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second half, the setting changes, and the play becomes a moving exploration of the harsh effects of illness. The British theatre lost a great talent when Wall passed away at the young age of 44.  
Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is the latest Irish playwright to enrich the English stage. All his plays are set in his hometown of Wexford, and this new piece looks at the decline of the fishing industry with his typical mix of strong characters, deep emotions, and unexpected humor. The play sometimes feels a bit aimless, but it builds to an exciting conclusion.  
Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This traditional thriller involves the idea of 'the perfect murder.' Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play a crime-writing duo who plan to kill each other. While the story is familiar, the plot twists are cleverly done.  
Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)

E. **The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes finds the brilliance in Jonson's great comedy about 17th-century con artists. First performed at the Swan in Stratford last year, the show works just as well on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce delivering excellent performances as the deceitful trio.  
Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's rich comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after its success at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is an often-overlooked classic.  
Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This charming new musical features playwright Alan Ayckbourn in a positive mood as he sets the Beauty and the Beast story in a London suburb. A beautiful score by John Pattison and a heartfelt celebration of romantic love make this show a true winner. London producers looking for a hit should visit Scarborough.  
Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's uninspired production of Shakespeare's most comedic play almost received a negative review, but it is saved by strong comic performances from Ron Cook as the French doctor Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Most of the cast seems a bit uncomfortable, which is understandable.  
Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
Another important revival of Granville Barker's work is now touring. This story about a seemingly respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son results in a wonderful play.  
Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)

**Simplified Text:**

**Hide and Seek**  
*Yvonne Coppard*  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a suspicious bookshop. She discovers that one of the rare customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to separate her from her friends, who are well-developed characters. When Emma's life is in danger, the story takes a dark turn. Her time trapped in the cellar of an old house is described in a powerful way. This book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It is an important and engaging read.

**Backtrack**  
*Peter Hunt*  
Two teenagers, Jack, who comes from a poor background, and Rill, who attends a fancy girls' school, team up when they learn that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915 that killed eight people. Different perspectives and documents—like maps, personal accounts, and railway histories—help the reader understand the incident, making it a clever and complex novel that requires careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer**  
*Ann Turnbull*  
Mary Dyer feels out of place in her family and male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes over managing the loft and winning prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story conveys a clear message: "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.

**Yaxley's Cat**  
*Robert Westall*  
In this chilling story, Robert Westall tells the tale from the perspective of a mature woman. Rose rents a cottage from Sepp Yaxley to escape her materialistic life and her arrogant husband, bringing her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why Yaxley disappeared, but the locals become hostile, putting their lives in danger. By the end, while the violence is controlled, Rose is troubled by her son's cold behavior. The story is gripping.

**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
*Harry Mazer*  
At the lower end of the family, there is Sam—overweight, talkative, and in awe of his cool cousin, Lisa, from the wealthy side of the family. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. The story has a slow pace at times but includes gentle humor and convincingly shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It appeals to both boys and girls, which is rare.

**Stanley's Aquarium**  
*Barry Faville*  
Barry Faville writes confidently and humorously, vividly describing his New Zealand setting and creating a likable first-person narrator. Robbie takes a job gardening for elderly Stanley, finding him interesting at first but later disturbing. When she discovers what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them, the story takes a thrilling turn while still providing sharp insights into character and relationships. It is unusual and compelling.

**Dodger**  
*Libby Gleeson*  
This is a painful and sad story about Mick, whose troubled relationships and difficult school life are told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher to a friend, and Mick's own notes. He learns to cope with the negative expectations of others and his low self-esteem through a role in a school play and the support of a caring first-year teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a very emotional read, especially at the end.

**Text: 'Science Defying Gravity'**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are using weightlessness to test their ideas. From the outside, the aircraft looked like any other. The pilot informed the 13 students from Europe and America that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964 and based on the Boeing 707 passenger plane. However, the inside was very different. It resembled a long white tunnel with few windows and lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, leaving only a few at the back where the nervous students sat, feeling anxious. 

For a year, these students had competed to take part in this flight, which was organized by the European Space Agency. They had to come up with creative experiments to conduct in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas earned a spot on this unique flight, which was like the most thrilling roller coaster ride imaginable. 

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that felt like a giant bird soaring upwards before diving back down. The goal was to create a moment of weightlessness at the top of each curve. When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the aircraft would rise higher due to its own speed before gravity pulled it back down. During the brief moments between rising and falling, everything inside the aircraft would become weightless, and the students would feel as if they were closer to the moon than to Earth.

The flight took off smoothly, but any thoughts of a regular passenger flight vanished when the pilot put the Boeing into a steep climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and we were thrown around the cabin. Then, the engines stopped, and we quickly experienced weightlessness. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. One small step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We floated without direction; up or down no longer made sense. Only gravity helps us understand where we are.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its dive. The return of gravity was sudden, causing some students to land hard. After completing the first curve, some students felt uneasy about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves allowed for ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device they built to investigate this, and one student managed to flip it over using a remote control. 

However, during the next curve, another student accidentally landed on the device, nearly damaging it. Meanwhile, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how the quality of metal joints is affected by the lack of gravity, which is important for building future space stations. Another group from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They hoped that once perfected, these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind.

After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unsteady, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would last a long time. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I already wanted to be an astronaut, but now I want it even more."

**Text: 'With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand'**

**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 

I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t experience any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which was actually winter there, so I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had the idea of buying a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can take the time to plant trees, then you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is suitable for planting trees. I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me, and I was eager to start. My family became enthusiastic as we went along. I began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it was one of those rainy winters. It rained a lot, almost every day we were planting. It seems strange to remember it as a happy time since I was often wet and cold. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for planting. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but then the rain would start, and I would have to deal with my damp jacket and wet boots. “The brain begins to take over and allows for many strange thoughts and reflections about life.” In that first year, I had a skilled tree-planter working with me, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck, filling it with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it’s heavy, but it gets easier as it gets lighter.

The hardest part of the job was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then set up three poles in a straight line. These poles guide your planting. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down and then turn around and come back. I enjoy hard physical work, and it helped me get fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically, finding a rhythm and using the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs; you train your body to perform a series of standard moves, making the work easier. You develop a regular process: taking the tree from the bag, digging a hole, placing it in the ground, stamping it down, and moving on. 

Mentally, it’s interesting. My mind starts to wander, allowing for many thoughts and reflections about life. A lot of my ideas about nature and our place in it began during those days. I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is satisfying because I planted them and feel a connection to their success. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such headlines make me anxious. However, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.

I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months, completely alone. I wrote my first book there, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I would write; in the afternoons, I would prune the trees, and in the evenings, I would do research. My connection to that area is still very strong. In many ways, it is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth. It is a powerful connection.

**Text: 'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**

"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have run an open farm in Somerset for six years, where we care for orphaned animals. The noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar, so I looked inside and found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were covered in fleas, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early lives underground. If they are orphaned, they often die from starvation without being found. These three cubs were brought to me by builders who accidentally disturbed their sett while laying drain pipes. Their mother was found dead, with her babies still suckling. Although the cubs were healthy, they were cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove for warmth. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I used a syringe to feed them, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic the feeling of their mother licking them. This helped them to relieve themselves. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though a bit unsteadily. They were happy with each other’s company and a heated pad as a substitute for their mother. 

However, three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed weak, even though he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet's examination showed that Willow had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding any animal, it is important not to let them drink too quickly, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that would have been hard to treat, even with antibiotics, because he was so small. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other cubs. 

Then, six days later, a local farmer, who had heard about my cubs, came to see me. He had found a single male cub abandoned by its mother behind some silage bags. He knew she would not return because the area had been disturbed, and the cub was cold and hungry. I named him Willow II. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon discovered why his mother had left him; he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly chewed and finally ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready to try other foods. 

At nearly five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, along with beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and even plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than other cubs that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms. By August, my cubs had started to become nocturnal and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where the long grass made it easy for them to chase each other. The cubs would get excited, fluff up their fur, and chase their tails. As "human badgers," we joined in their fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and had colorful reactions to being nipped. 

During two of these late-night walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely searching for food because they had to expand their territory. Badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive towards others that enter their area. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we put sheet metal over the gate to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and there was such interest that we started a campaign to build a sett on the farm for the badgers to live in. With help from others, we designed a new home for them. My son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate that faced their usual walking path. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside from a darkened area. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became so excited about the tunnels that they forgot about their walks. 

The cost of building was higher than we expected, but a local bus company called Badgerline sponsored part of the project, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I quietly returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. These days, I don’t walk with them as often, especially since they don’t fully wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only occasionally because she has joined a nearby sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to greet me before they dash off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

**Text: In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his most important achievements was charting the 'variations of the compass' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', refer to the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Understanding this angle was crucial for sailors to correct their compasses and navigate accurately.

Halley, one of only two men in England at that time paid to do scientific research, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip was cut short due to crew problems, but he later sailed again. This journey took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans'. More advanced charts based on his work helped sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made them less accurate.

Dr. Clark plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting his efforts. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist's life. "Halley led a remarkable life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also researched geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and had other interests."

During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton while he wrote *Principia Mathematica*, a key work in physics. Dr. Clark believes retracing Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements similar to Halley's but with more accurate instruments. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is constantly changing. The data collected will help improve the current model of the Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field.

"It is common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field," Dr. Clark explains. "You need to know true north to measure the direction. On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill in any gaps in the Atlantic Ocean coverage. Ground-based measurements will also be useful for comparison.

Halley's Atlantic journey was significant as it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain to pursue his interest in declination. Does Dr. Clark have the qualifications to succeed in his voyage? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has already sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.

Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? "I am willing to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**Text: 'POWER DRESSING'**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the often critical hens. This behavior raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: how could birds develop such extravagant features in a competitive world? How do they manage to survive with such a burden? 

Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade, a century after Darwin's death, to find answers. Darwin believed that living beings evolved through natural selection, meaning that the individuals best suited to their environment are more likely to survive and reproduce. However, he thought that being the "fittest" usually meant being the strongest or fastest. In contrast, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, leading Darwin to suggest a different process called "sexual selection." He argued that females are attracted to beauty for its own sake.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens preferred males with the most impressive tails, it must be because those males had some other important quality that helped them survive, even if it wasn't obvious to humans. According to Wallace, the tail was not just for show; it was a sign of something beneficial.

Today, researchers still debate these ideas. Studying the natural behavior of peafowl is challenging, but the 200 birds at Whipsnade, which live in a semi-wild environment and are used to people, provide a unique opportunity for research. Petrie and her team are investigating two main questions: Do peahens really choose the males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have any real advantages, as Wallace suggested, or is it just for show, as Darwin believed?

Observations show that the hens do seem to prefer the males with the most eye-spots on their tails, which are related to tail length. Males with more eye-spots attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways. William Hamilton from Oxford University proposed that showy male birds are often free of parasites, and their bright feathers signal their health. There is evidence for this in other bird species, but Petrie and her team have not yet been able to study the internal parasites of the Whipsnade peacocks.

This year, Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive males with those of less attractive ones. Are the children of the attractive males healthier and growing faster? If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is based on practical benefits.

There is also an interesting theory from mathematician and biologist R A Fisher, known as "Fisher's Runaway." He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that tail, and her daughters will inherit her preference for long tails. This could lead to a cycle where males with the longest tails attract the most mates, reinforcing the preference for long tails in females. Modern computer models suggest that this process could explain the evolution of the peacock's tail, supporting Darwin's idea that females might eventually select beauty for its own sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix traditional and modern elements. He applied this idea in his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London showcases many beautiful yachts filled with new technology. Most of these boats are descendants of a major design change that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat rests quietly in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although it was designed last year, it looks like it is 100 years old, which might make you think its owner is a romantic. Perhaps I am, but I’m not sure. 

This boat benefits from the charm of classic design, but modern technology has made the process easier. However, it is important to note that advanced technology often separates sailors from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going sailing in the first place. I am not saying that sailors should go back to facing every difficulty. I believe it is essential for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Dealing with a flapping sail is surely part of a sailor's experience. 

Why should we give up common sense and move our steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a less secure spot near the front? Unfortunately, this change creates a cabin that resembles an ocean liner, with a bed larger than one at home. For me, a boat should always be a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner noted that it had all the comforts but no luxuries. During my time with Hirta, I learned how true this was. 

Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the kindest and easiest boat I have ever sailed. However, classic boats require a lot of maintenance, and when I injured my back, I realized I could no longer care for her. I looked for a younger boat but found none that met my needs, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. 

The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett are skilled with computer design programs, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin before moving to the computer. After creating a set of lines, he carved a model, just like boat builders did in the past. We reviewed the initial design and then made adjustments using the computer. The next version was almost perfect, and by the time we finished, the design was just right. 

The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She has a timeless look, moves beautifully at sea, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, creates a peaceful atmosphere. This may be because she was designed solely as a sailing boat, without considering any furniture we might add. This traditional approach works well. In her calm presence, she proves that you don’t need to follow trends to find happiness, and sometimes it is wise to learn from history. Built with wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. Therefore, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a true sailing vessel.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was excited to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started attending body conditioning classes and tried as many classes as I could, like stretch and tone, yoga, and body alignment. All the instructors are very well trained. I was amazed at how flexible I felt as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy (which helped me relax), seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial, which lasts an hour, truly makes you feel rejuvenated. The staff in the treatment rooms were incredibly friendly and professional. The atmosphere is full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow plans to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. Bicycles are available for riding around the grounds. If you prefer to relax, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I will definitely return. This is the perfect getaway for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me!  
Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I walked up the large staircase into the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can avoid talking to others if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone receives a medical check-up, which includes an examination and a check of weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt a bit strange since I am healthy. However, I was impressed that a shoulder issue found during the examination was quickly shared with the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and individual sessions. Each patient follows a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting, but I was still hungry enough to get a bad headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a light diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and well-presented. You receive a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm and does not claim to be one. It is a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef prepares rich sauces and delicious creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, so I could work off some of the tempting treats. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A major attraction is the sports injury clinic. I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside nearby.  
Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats its guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-acclaimed restaurant, serves dishes that are absolutely delightful. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed feeling very happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym using exercise equipment to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other reports my fellow journalists would write about fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments. Cliveden offers all these if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. The best because it is the most delicious I have ever tasted. The worst because it has 360 calories, which can be a setback if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose a relaxing oil blend and fell asleep twice during the massage. I returned to my room and had the best night's sleep in years. The facilities are modern and well-organized, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, making it easy to schedule appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a diverse mix, including football teams, mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month.  
Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences; genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This suggests that the traits that make us human are a recent development in our evolutionary history. Our ability to create art and other unique human traits likely comes from just a small number of our genes. This is a significant responsibility for such a limited set of genes. 

Recent studies of animal behavior have shown that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree rather than kind. For instance, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools; chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to crack open clams. Regarding language, monkeys have simple warning calls for predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. These findings suggest that the differences between humans and animals are not as clear-cut as once believed, with art being one of the few significant distinctions.

However, if human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it is curious that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments created by Cro-Magnons.

If we argue that our recent artistic explosion sets us apart, we must consider how our art differs from that of animals. Three common claims are made: human art is non-utilitarian, it is created for aesthetic pleasure, and it is learned rather than instinctive. 

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." A biologist might interpret this to mean that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike most animal behaviors. While some human art serves a purpose in communication, it is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong has clear functions, such as defending territory or attracting mates, which help transmit their genes. By this measure, human art does seem different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure, which also seems reasonable. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy the beauty of their songs, but they mainly sing during mating season, suggesting they do not sing just for pleasure. Again, this makes human art appear unique.

The third claim is that human art is learned rather than instinctive. Different human groups have distinct art styles that are learned. For example, songs sung in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. However, these differences are not genetically inherited. People from different cultures can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some bird species are born with the ability to sing their specific songs, even if they have never heard them before.

The role of learning in human art is evident in how quickly our art styles change. Roman writers described geese honking 2,000 years ago, and they still do today. However, human art evolves rapidly; even a casual museum visitor can tell that a twentieth-century painting is more recent than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when a painting was made and who created it, but they might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day for his own enjoyment and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 at London's Institute of Contemporary Art, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot claim.

These paintings by our closest relatives blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the ape paintings did not serve a specific purpose; they were created for the satisfaction of the painter. One might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend their work as a means of communication, while the apes did not care to share their paintings. However, this argument is not entirely convincing, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction rather than communication.

**Text: An Amazing Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be full of brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes squinting to see far away on their journeys into the unknown. Nowadays, you rarely find such characters in stories, or even in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, which means "once entered, you never come out." Local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that incredible journey while sitting calmly at home with his family. The team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It later turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back since nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was surprisingly good to us."

Anyone reading his remarkable story will be surprised by the word "good." The team faced terrible hardships: severe stomach illness, extreme temperatures, intense thirst, and the loss of part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we didn’t struggle the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."

"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability to do it. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of how hard it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert does not compare."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — the excitement of it all. We were lifted by our sense of purpose. I find it hard now to fit into the sameness of modern life."

**Simplified Text:**

Life was becoming overwhelming for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy the benefits of manual work. Many people love technology because it provides us with amazing devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, this reliance on technology has led us to believe that it is essential and acceptable. The truth is clear: using our hands does not consume energy or harm the environment. 

After a frustrating experience with a broken word processor, which cost me a lot to fix, I began to question whether gadgets are really worth the money and hassle. Am I as dependent on technology as I think? Gradually, I have stopped using household gadgets as they break down. This makes me wonder what "time" technology actually gives us. Is it just time to engage in more activities that require even more gadgets? If that’s the case, then the marketing experts have tricked us.

When my broken gadget started making strange noises, even after being unplugged, I left it outside, where it now sits quietly like a ghost. I no longer feel tied to a noisy machine, and I can take my time with my sewing. I have always been a bit scared of electric machines that move quickly towards my fingers. The best part is that I can easily carry my sewing supplies with me wherever I go.

Of course, there are some gadgets I appreciate. After a year without a washing machine, I realized how valuable it is. However, losing some gadgets has brought me unexpected joy. Feeling that we were spending too much time in front of the television, I returned our rented color TV and switched back to a small black-and-white one. This change has made us focus more on what is truly worth watching, and we now spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, or enjoying other hobbies. One of my hobbies is sewing, and I no longer use my old Singer sewing machine, which has become a plant table. Since I cannot afford to replace it, I have started sewing by hand.

We often think we cannot live without our gadgets, and while we may resist the idea of living without them, we should remember the hard lives of those who worked long hours without machines. Computers now do many tasks for us quickly and even entertain us. However, the time I spend sewing is not boring; it has many benefits. I can sew while listening to the radio, talking to family and friends, or even watching TV if the task is simple. I feel good sitting by the fire with a cup of tea while I sew.

I used to think with dread about women who spent hours sewing by hand. I imagined it was tiring and difficult. But now, I find it calming and satisfying to create something with my hands. I am surprised at how quickly I can finish projects, and my life feels slower and more relaxed. I no longer feel the pressure to rush from one task to another. I have also taken back control of my kitchen, where I can wash dishes and daydream, enjoying this simple activity.

Now, I look around my home and wonder if we really need all our gadgets, like the freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. In fact, we could save a lot of money by doing without electric lights!

Text: 'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems to be a man in a hurry. When I arrive at his workshop, located under a railway arch in East London, he greets me with a quick handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It is not clear if this brusque manner is genuine or if he is hiding a shy side. However, looking around the workshop shows that Hurst is very busy, with good reason not to waste any time. The arched space is filled with half-finished furniture and wooden planks in many natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built a strong reputation. His order book is always full for several months ahead, even though he does not actively promote himself. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right choice. 

Finding a furniture-maker is not difficult, especially in the countryside where the craft is thriving. However, it is harder to find a cabinet-maker who focuses on creating beautifully crafted furniture with clean, simple designs. "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many call themselves furniture-makers," Hurst says tiredly. As a craftsman with high standards, he is often disappointed by some modern furniture. "I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people accept." He criticizes poor-quality, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who produce second-rate items. This pursuit of perfection is clearly a key to Hurst's success, along with his talent. He is not shy about his skills. In fact, his strong self-confidence is surprising given his initial brusque manner. "I have a huge natural ability," he says seriously. "I have always been good at making things." If it were not for his modesty towards the end of our conversation, I would have thought he was completely serious.

Hurst is self-taught. So how did he learn his craft? "I asked the right questions and picked it all up," he says casually. Most of his work comes from private clients. "I used to do some commercial work for companies, but it was soul-destroying." Some clients come back to him repeatedly. "You end up doing their whole house. That is very satisfying." However, he honestly admits that not all client relationships are easy. "The most frustrating clients are those who don’t know what they want, and then decide too late. My favorite clients are the exacting ones." 

While Hurst has every reason to be proud, he is also generous in praising others when it is deserved. With a sudden touch of modesty, he says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other craftsmen. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham," which is a leading college of furniture design. However, he is also very critical of those craftsmen who "try to be artists and take a year to make one piece." He has little patience for degree shows, where students display their work while trying to make fashion statements. "That can be pretentious. A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something people can really use." 

Hurst may be confident and brusque, but you could never call him or his work pretentious. In fact, his final words show a practical approach to his craft and a humility that contrasts with his earlier self-confidence. "After all, I am only making furniture," he says as I leave.'

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.

The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and to help us feel better.

The second theory focuses on learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.

The third theory is about energy. It states that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and odd habits. It could be a love for entering newspaper competitions, a habit of collecting beer mats, or a tendency to write letters to the editor about various topics. Eccentricity is a way of expressing our individuality. Inside us, there is often a struggle between two opposing forces. One is called individualism, which represents our desire to be unique, and the other is conformity, which represents our need to fit in. For many, the desire to be accepted and liked by others is stronger than the desire to stand out and be different.

People with unusual hobbies, strong opinions, or unconventional behavior often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests or concerns. The key word here is 'common.' They seek others who understand what their friends and family might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, can be comforting. Most of us feel a tension between individualism and conformity. While we often follow the crowd, we may also resist the idea that we are doing so. We feel a need to express our individuality, like when a man at a bar declares, "I say what I think," or when a newcomer insists, "You must take me as I am."

At any moment, we can choose to embrace our individuality. Many people succeed in their careers by doing just that. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, has said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it with determination, you will surprise many people." However, this assertion of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they may be considered eccentric. 

The most important aspect of eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. A true eccentric is not focused on what others think; they act according to their true selves. This sets eccentrics apart from enthusiasts, practical jokers, clever criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These individuals are aware of the world around them and often act in response to it. Some want to impress society, while others want to escape from it, but they are all conscious of societal expectations. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives freely, without concern for others' opinions.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet some of the great thinkers in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She has been at the center of environmental issues in post-war Europe. She combined her experiences from various environmental movements into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, I found that she helped me understand these complex issues better than anyone else. Choosing her book was more difficult. It could have been *Only One Earth* or *Progress for a Small Planet*, but I believe *The Home of Man* is her most important work. It focuses on the rapid growth of cities worldwide, while also addressing the larger themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none have matched its impact.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read *Signals for Survival* by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of guano in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the fascinating world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony becomes a different experience; what seems chaotic turns out to be a well-organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings, created from years of observing birds, show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is *My Family and Other Animals* by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation, but it also defined my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my world brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and beauty—a small version of a world worth saving. Many believe humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, viewing all living beings as a family, intertwined and inseparable. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I discovered *The Shell Bird Book* by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion, which were described as being painted "with particular skill and charm." These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. However, *The Shell Bird Book* offered much more. Along with the beautiful paintings, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative responses to nature are just as valid as scientific ones. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new possibilities for myself.

**Text: DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five leading British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers; they are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually more accepting of bad reviews. They believe that any mention in the press can help sales, as readers will want to see for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinions about a book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, ideally in a positive way. Book reviewing is better now than it was 40 years ago, as it is more varied and less exclusive. However, there is still a tendency to overlook paperbacks, which many people read. Weekly summaries of reviews are often not enough, and original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. Still, publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and an author. A good review from a trusted source can boost sales, especially if there are several positive reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing; without them, we would struggle. Our books are usually not by well-known authors, so we rely on literary editors to give our books space in their publications. Good reviews are much more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. The impact of reviews on sales is complex. Good reviews can launch a book and a career, but they need to be supported by other factors like recommendations from readers, strong responses from booksellers, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the United States, it is straightforward: a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, however, booksellers often ignore reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of great reviews for people to notice a good writer. Interestingly, some poorly received books or those without reviews can still sell very well. The situation is unpredictable, although non-fiction reviews often focus more on the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they actually sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it failed to sell because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the reviewer's name matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers praised a book, people paid attention. Today, it can be just as effective if an unexpected reviewer writes a clever or original review, which can encourage readers to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, this skill is still practiced in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special personalized item," he says. Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something unique that reflects the man's interests or profession.

Graham's work is quite different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked the surprise gift he made for his wife and started asking him to create weathervanes for them. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he explains. Graham then decided to focus on making weathervanes as a business.

Before this, he trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Five years ago, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles: she became the main breadwinner while he took care of their children and built the weathervane business. He has no regrets about this change. "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."

Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs available, as they are still popular. "People seem to appreciate handmade items," Graham says. "They like the chance to own something a bit different."

Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I feel satisfied when a simple shape becomes something almost lifelike," he explains. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." He adds that with more people moving to the countryside, many want to add a special touch to their homes, which has helped crafts like his.

Graham is now busier than ever, sending flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world, especially in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Text: 'Beginner Takes All'**

Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.

The beginning of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and hoping to be a director. Things started badly when a film project he had been working on, *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He felt disappointed and worried because it had been two years since he had earned any money, and that film was his only hope to calm his angry bank manager.

A sensible person in Evans' situation would have found a job. He could have returned to being a television executive or started a television project that was on hold. Instead, he made a decision that many, including himself, thought was crazy. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.

Although he acted on impulse, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. It was inspired by a farrier he met in Dartmoor while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive for no reason. Its owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These people were known as "horse whisperers." Evans was fascinated and began to research this topic, initially planning to write a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after feeling disillusioned with the film industry, he decided to write the story as a book.

Throughout the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was watching people, but I felt very alone and thought my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and here I was, deeply in debt and worried about how to support my children, wondering if it was all a mistake."

By the end of August, after returning home and writing the first half of the book, he felt the pressure from his bank manager. He needed to know if it was worth continuing. He bravely showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for an estimate, he suggested Evans might receive $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some of his debts, and it was more than that. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer*, with at least two more months of work ahead. $30,000 was a challenging amount to consider. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, along with the first two hundred pages of the novel, he sent this summary to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "I said, 'What?' And he replied, 'It's okay, I just feel something good is happening.'"

What happened next is now part of publishing history. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we just sat there in shock. We had never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also did not send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent in the US, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief." 

As they all agreed to this amount, they decided to present their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called one after another, asking for the chance to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel. Evans shared this story with me while we enjoyed coffee on the wooden porch of his home, surrounded by a beautiful garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's all been like a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very challenging, and I don't want to become an employee of these people I like who have paid me so much money. I would hate to write a draft or two and then hear them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we’ll bring in someone else.'"

He said he would stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was no longer sure he wanted to make it. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Text: 'Young Masters'**

Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to the world of chess. Chess has become more of a young person's game. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now, at 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 

The game of chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Now, winning is the main goal for modern chess players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high, as players must make their moves within a set time using a chess clock. If they don’t, they lose immediately. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks, increasing the pressure on players. 

In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much of it now happens off the board, including psychological strategies. Players must prepare thoroughly before matches, especially since computers can store millions of chess games and provide quick access to information about opponents. In recent matches, players have used teams of assistants to analyze each other’s strategies. 

Preparation for the opening moves of a game is crucial and can determine the outcome. Today, there are more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes worldwide. Success in chess requires both mental and physical effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must maintain focus throughout. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The presence of the chess clock adds to the stress, often leading to a frantic rush at the end of the game, where players have only seconds to make their moves. 

In these moments, players must act quickly and decisively, showcasing skills that any athlete would admire. The game can become a fierce battle where determination and the will to win are key. For top players, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to secure a tournament victory. Chess tournaments usually last 9-11 days, with games played every day, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. 

For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months due to exhaustion, with Karpov losing about 10 kg. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game seem even more puzzling. If he has returned for the money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. However, if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Text: Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.

A. Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three well-received plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Despite his talent, the most surprising thing about Nick is that he had never seen or read a play before writing *Peaches*. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he explains. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I understand the challenges. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After completing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he says. "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational setting. It was very inspiring."

B. Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even back in Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his partnership with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.

C. Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known when he starred in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare and comfortable position, especially since he has just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear that such recognition was likely. Encouraged by his mother, he moved from leading roles in school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he spent four years. "I was basically using acting to avoid doing homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to pursue it because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for doing good work."

D. Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is very different from mine," he says. "They want a big hit, but for me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were moments when I felt very down, and I had been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."

E. Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won more awards and honors than many people twice his age. He is already well-known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I chose not to go to university, but I realized I needed to after I got bored stuffing envelopes at a theater." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they always thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, his move into novels is indeed bold. "My poetry has a structure, and there's less chance of making a big mistake," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more words that could be bad. My main goal is to avoid falling into a routine where I just produce work without caring about its quality."

**Simplified Text:**

A. Isabel, our main character in this quirky novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn't want to associate with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance novels and is looking for Mr. Right. She worries that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a clever, shy child named Francis With.
