Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing, taking readers back to the gentler times of the 1940s and 1950s, filled with dime stores, old cars, and radios.

C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poet, he shares his feelings with his wife's ex-husband. The poet writes poor poetry, which bothers Richard, and she is also trying to get his help for her wrongly imprisoned brother. However, the way the author resolves these issues is even more interesting. He moves the story forward with a strong sense of humor and carefully examines relationships, making it an enjoyable and clever read.

D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become connected for 25 years through life and death. At the beginning of this long novel, one of the friends, James Hudson, an American businessman, is starting a newspaper that his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one of them married) was killed years earlier. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, all written well. This book allows readers to really get to know the characters.

E. This touching and funny story, written by a top American author, follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake. To make up for it, he becomes a 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor. The story explores deep emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that perfectly balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 

A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a significant contribution to development. While they can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a large fee to participate in this work. This money, if given directly to a local community, could pay for more labor than the individual volunteer could provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often lack the technical skills or professional experience needed. Therefore, many studies question whether gap year volunteering is mainly driven by a desire to help others or if young people are more interested in gaining experience that will benefit their careers. However, these projects may help develop individuals who will act ethically in favor of those who are less fortunate in their future careers.

B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, active participation in global issues through civic organizations, and the growth of international social networks among everyday people. In this case, the overall benefits for both volunteers and host communities can contribute to the greater good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may provide them with a broader perspective and career advantages, but it will not significantly help those who lack access to international volunteer opportunities. Volunteers will continue to benefit personally while using host organizations and communities to advance their own goals.

C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving charity by wealthy Westerners. At its best, it can provide benefits and challenges to volunteers and the organizations they work with, while allowing for the exchange of skills, knowledge, and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and foster a lifelong commitment to addressing unequal power relations and the root causes of poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.

D. Volunteer tourism aligns with the growing trend of personal strategies to help others. These limited strategies, focused on making a small difference, can seem positive in a time when political action is less popular. The personal aspect appears appealing as it avoids large government and business involvement. However, it also overlooks the need for representative government and reduces development to individual acts of charity, which often do not address the deeper issues faced by poor rural communities. While skepticism about volunteering is often misplaced, volunteer tourism can sometimes involve simple, commendable charity. However, when it is promoted as sustainable development and gap-year companies market their programs as such, it reflects a decline in the understanding of development issues. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from recognizing global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports

Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, which included myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

The 'dual alarm function' advertised with one model does not let you wake up to the buzzer, snooze for a bit, and then finally get out of bed, as I first thought. The instruction booklet suggests using this function to set two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. But who really lives their life like that? Since this model costs about the same as the second one we tested, having a cassette player is a good deal—you can fall asleep to your favorite tapes and wake up to a day without news. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but we wished it was smaller. It is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave enough space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. Also, I'm a bit paranoid and always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't go off." This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," even though the clock he tested "kept getting stuck at 16:00."

I was impressed by the digital display, with its stylish grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze bar lets you tap it easily with your eyes closed. Unfortunately, the smooth buttons, which felt like pebbles, made me want to touch them like piano keys, which caused problems when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if someone pulls the plug to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner; we all liked this feature. However, we found it difficult to set up, though completing it made us feel "cool" and sophisticated.

Tom Granger described this model, which has a built-in lamp, as "unbelievably tacky." He said, "You have to pull the strange light out of its socket to make it work, which makes me question the quality of the rest." He complained that he had to read the instruction booklet twice to get it to work; the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light was hard to position; you could never read by it—it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like "action stations" on a submarine and made me want to throw the whole thing across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, with its bright colors and matching strap, it appealed to the child in Tom Granger and me. "I would choose this one because it stands out," he said. In fact, the traditional design of the controls made it the only one we could set up without reading the instruction booklet. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute margin for error; the manual says, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges laughed at this idea, saying this model was "terribly fiddly" and "completely useless."

The simplest and cheapest of all the models tested scored points with Tom Granger because it "seemed very standard and took up little space," and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. "It's easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed all the buttons correctly, so you can't be confident it will work." He accepted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model definitely works; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All species of hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, making them more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up. Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; some will stay awake all year if conditions are suitable.

**Text: Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land safely, but it can be frightening. Sometimes I don't feel well or the weather is bad, but I push through. Having a career outside of skiing is tough because we train for ten months each year. I have to give up a lot of my social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally—it's a young sport."

B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and ended up winning because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was incredible since I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment needed."

C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because very few girls' schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to a lack of stability in the women's team. However, I enjoy it and love staying fit, plus there is a good social aspect."

D. **Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world without realizing how vast it is! I found Britain too small and safe. I was very determined and disliked being controlled by others. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the hardest experience due to the pain. I walked 50 miles a day with very little sleep and many blisters, but I set a record! I had to succeed because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."

E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, especially on highways. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I approach a corner, men think they must beat me, so I've faced many tough moments! You need to be competitive and assertive. It's hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It's great that more women are joining the sport every year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing is striving for perfection and aiming for the perfect lap."

F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before races, and I really push myself—if I don’t, I don’t feel good. I’ve often wondered why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also less for women. However, we have now formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**Simplified Text:**

The day I met Picasso, Richard Cork remembers how, as a 78-year-old student, he encountered one of the most famous artists of the century. Even from a distance, eating lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes, Picasso was easy to recognize. I was an 18-year-old student, traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old, unreliable van while waiting to start university. After running out of money, I found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have a sketchbook with me when I met the elderly artist.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually worked alone in the hills. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have approached him to ask for his signature. I was nervous as I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below. Picasso's art, even when abstract, often connected to real things. The lines he drew might represent a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbour, which he could see from where he was sitting.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was worse than my French, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him the Maestro, which made it hard for me to speak. Still, I managed to tell Picasso about my strong interest in art and my admiration for his work. After a while, I went back to the boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that the lunch was still going on. "Is that all?" he asked, looking at the signature. "Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this opportunity? You might not get another chance, and he probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."

With my sketchbook under my arm, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was best not to ask if I could draw his portrait, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, leaned my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and began to draw. When Picasso noticed, he smiled playfully and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny and strange expressions—rolling his eyes, sticking out his tongue, and making silly shapes with his hands. It was like he was a natural clown. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit challenged me to keep going. Despite his antics, I sensed he was testing my determination.

Eventually, Picasso relaxed and allowed me to study him without distractions. I saw how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed more like a fit 60-year-old than a man about to turn 84. His dark eyes were youthful and intense, and I tried to capture that in my drawing. He seemed distant and alone, even with friends around him. His playful behavior hid a serious side. He let his friends talk while he sat quietly, focused on his own thoughts.

When the American lady told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. However, Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketchbook, he nodded approvingly. To my surprise, he then said it was his turn to draw. I quickly handed him my crayon, and he made a few quick, confident strokes on the paper. In seconds, he sketched a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one eye onto my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. After checking with the American, she explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Still, I look back now and feel grateful. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a lot to me.

**Text: 'Shopping Strategies'**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? Here, we explain the techniques that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

A. **Freshness Appeal**  
Supermarkets understand that customers value fresh produce. They often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store or display house plants to create a fresh atmosphere. In-store bakeries that fill the air with the smell of fresh bread also attract shoppers. The colors used in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh food. However, most items sold in supermarkets, like frozen foods and cleaning products, do not match this fresh image.

B. **Product Placement**  
The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales, especially in supermarkets. With advanced stock-control systems, supermarkets can identify which areas attract the most shoppers. High-profit items are often placed in these areas, while 'eye-level' shelves are highly sought after by manufacturers. Special offer bins, known as 'dump bins', attract bargain hunters. Another strategy is 'complementation', where related items, like desserts next to ice cream, are placed together.

C. **Strategic Layout**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost staples like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to walk past more expensive items, increasing the chances of impulse buys. Chain stores may also position their popular products away from the entrance, hoping loyal customers will search for them and encounter other tempting items along the way.

D. **Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from the idea of selling many items cheaply. Instead, they create a 'boutique' feel by showcasing a limited selection of fashionable clothing, making it seem exclusive. Their success comes from both good store design and stylish clothing.

E. **Total Costs Matter**  
Food shoppers often focus more on the total cost of their shopping trip rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items, so not everything is cheap. They may even sell some staples at a loss to attract customers, a strategy known as 'loss leaders'. They achieve low prices by buying in bulk or offering prominent displays, which can lead to discounts from manufacturers.

F. **Pricing Strategies**  
In chain stores, shoppers tend to buy fewer items and pay more attention to individual prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can influence buying decisions. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

G. **Lighting Effects**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural light, helping customers see the true colors of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to highlight fresh produce.

H. **Store Navigation**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, known as the 'Yellow Brick Road', encourage customers to explore. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use wood or marble for pathways, leading shoppers to more inviting carpeted sales areas.

I. **In-Store Promotions**  
As you enter a supermarket, large colorful images of delicious food catch your eye, especially if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing 'video trolleys' that display advertisements as you shop. Sensors trigger ads related to the products nearby, aiming to attract impulse buyers and potentially increasing sales by about 30%.

**Text: Sea, Ice & Rock**

Mountaineer Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for reaching the summit of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book: *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could show me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, and I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

After a while, we reached a steep drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how. When I finished, Robin politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit worried, but he lowered himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion that we combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural extension of our Skye adventure. 

I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always consulted the crew first. Most of the time, no one dared to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing challenging and quite boring. The moments of crisis were easy to handle because of the adrenaline, but spending day after day in the middle of the sea was hard for me. I prefer land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was also cramped: six people on a 32-foot yacht designed for four. At least on a mountain expedition, you can get some space from each other. When we reached Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times while climbing when if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be very careful. I underestimated how difficult the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether we could get it through the ice and if it was still intact. Yet he supported our decision to try climbing the mountain again.

The only time we had a serious issue was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns keeping watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I expressed this to him. Robin quickly reassured me that I was misunderstanding the situation. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we didn’t truly get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, existing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains that turned to carbon near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and areas near the Caucasus mountains, early humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, which in Ancient Britain were called 'windings.' They were very different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge included cider-making and was brought to Britain during Roman times, along with dessert apples like Decio, introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and Norman varieties quickly became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple types, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
Several apple varieties became common in Britain during the thirteenth century. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term 'costermonger,' meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This trend continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them valuable possessions. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, or 'Johnny Appleseed.' Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious beliefs led to many folktales about him, including one that said he was so kind to animals that he even slept with bears.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found something growing from the roots of a dead tree. This shoot became an apple tree that produced a new type of apple, which Hiatt named 'Hawkey.' After he showed it at a fruit exhibition, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous modern apple was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and rejected her parents' criminal past. She worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales, and was known as 'Granny Smith' because she managed the family farm and orchard, which provided their income. In 1868, she found a small tree growing among discarded fruit. She moved it, and soon she was harvesting the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she said, "Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the fruit and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, from Himachal Pradesh in northern India to luxury orchards in Africa. However, most apples are grown commercially and come from only a few varieties, often chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, rather than for their taste. This trend of uniformity is reducing the variety of apples and affecting their flavor. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from a century ago. However, consumers are starting to ask for more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to save the diversity of apples or any other food. We must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Text: Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique and interesting destinations with original itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last between 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people and are led by experienced guides. This allows you to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local cultures. The experience is enriching for all travelers.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport during our trips, often on the same journey. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the character of the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting individuals who are ready to embrace new experiences. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are designed for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most participants are between 25 and 55 years old, with about half being couples and the rest solo travelers.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip with Explore Worldwide is unique, so we categorize our adventures into 8 different themes, highlighting key activities. Each category showcases special features of a tour, but many other factors contribute to the overall success of our trips, such as unique locations, cultural encounters, and personal experiences.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural aspect, with some focusing primarily on local cultures and historical sites. Destinations of cultural interest include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Short walks of 2-4 hours to visit lesser-known sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing thrilling encounters with animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might have the chance to explore the wild on foot, track mountain gorillas, or go canoeing. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel accommodations.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara, the Maya of Mexico, or the Huli of Papua New Guinea. Many of these cultures are under threat, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing cultural and environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walking through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. Some involve village-to-village hiking, with overnight stays in local homes or simple huts. Destinations include Spain, Greece, Morocco, and many more. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer a few challenging treks for experienced hikers, sometimes at high altitudes. These trips may involve staying with local people or camping in stunning mountain ranges like the Himalayas and the Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you won’t need to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an unforgettable adventure. We visit places like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert, offering unique experiences that few people get to enjoy.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats. We sail through Upper Egypt on traditional feluccas, use wooden yachts in Turkey, and ferry between islands in Greece and Thailand. Our trips in the Galapagos Islands are aboard a small motor yacht, allowing us to explore unique wildlife habitats.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River journeys can last from a few hours to several days, using inflatable rafts or navigating exciting whitewater with skilled guides. No prior experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of lush landscapes and vibrant jungles.

Text: 'Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner and one of Britain's best 10,000-metre runners, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain path leads off a quiet road from Nairobi. This path marks the beginning of the climb up Mount Kenya, the country’s highest peak. This beautiful but isolated place is called Nanyuki. For the past three years, it has been my base for winter altitude training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until my fourth winter training trip to Kenya. On this trip, I participated in my first race in Kenya's thin air and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss. Training at high altitude increases the number of red blood cells, which helps carry more oxygen. This has been proven by the success of many Kenyan runners. My first race in Africa, which took place before my time at the training camp, was also significant. It was the first international cross-country race ever held in Africa, in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience, as of the 41 runners who finished ahead of me, only 3 were not Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I believe Kenyan success is not only due to altitude. Kenyan runners are known for their simple approach to the sport. Their running style looks effortless, their diet is straightforward, and they seem to enjoy competing. However, the most basic question about their success is how they train. My time with the Kenyan runners at their training camp provided some answers. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mt Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. It is quite basic, with few comforts. The athletes live with regular students and share rooms with five others in simple dormitories. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The day starts at six. We would wake up and gather for a briefing from the coaches before the morning run. "Run easy, you have a hard day ahead," the coach would say. Each day, we covered about 40 kilometers, which is just under a marathon distance. The only exception was Sunday, when we only ran 20 kilometers, which was a welcome break from the rest of the week’s training. Outside of running, life was simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth was enough for morning preparations. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs, eaten in a small, dimly lit dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar: ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running in the evening, we would drive to one of the streams from Mt Kenya's melting glaciers to bathe. By the time I left the camp, I had a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the hard training, and the passion for success might be the real reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.'

**Text: The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This issue is not just due to the recession; advertising began to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are more serious and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about mass markets and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become more divided. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not. This is a major reason why advertising is not working well.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen each year. If you buy a new car, it is likely provided by your employer, and if not, you may only buy one every three years. You probably do not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you consider all the other products and services, it is very likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In comparison, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are individually listed and analyzed. The average consumer buys about 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are due to advertising. This means that only about 4 percent of advertising is effective. 

When you watch TV tonight, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. Most people find that only about one in 16 commercials (6 percent) are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent of the commercials are likely wasted. You might think you are different and that you are not influenced by advertising, but most people feel the same way. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. 

There is always some waste in advertising because not every person who sees an ad will buy the product. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many advertisements have shown that it can work. Advertising needs to reach a large number of people to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as advertisers cannot know in advance who will be interested. 

Even with careful targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail campaigns do not achieve a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between media advertising and personal selling. A salesperson might succeed with every potential client they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use media at all; they could contact those individuals directly.

Any advertiser who can attract one million new customers (about 2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For popular soap brands, gaining a million extra customers would be a great success. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can win over 2 percent of the population would be considered very successful, and this is just a small part of the population. While mass media can be a cost-effective way to reach people, if advertising is to improve, its messages will need to be more carefully targeted than ever before.

**Simplified Text:**

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Greenest Home**

Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting features. First, it is home to Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral. Writers who care about the environment admire the pagan 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in the cathedral's thirteenth-century chapter house. 

The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. This house is designed to be very eco-friendly. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into compost for their garden, and heat their home using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. 

You might not notice the house at first because it looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the burnt-orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and received approval from planners, even though it is in a conservation area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will find it very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated, with special triple-glazed windows that keep out noise. 

Once inside, you must take off your shoes, as Robert insists. The atmosphere is calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is designed to be draught-proof. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to eliminate the need for mains water as well. They designed composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.

Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness." The only medieval feature of the house is its design: the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, goes up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.

Soon, they will install £20,000 worth of solar panels in the garden, which will help the house generate more electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will produce extra electricity, enough to eventually charge an electric car. The only heating source is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they claim to use only during the coldest winter days. 

When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no draughts and everything was at the same temperature. He noted that a woman in the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggested that people living in older homes should adapt to living like people did in the past, but this idea might be hard to accept.

The secret to the house's success is its simple design, which means there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were bought from a local builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen, making the house affordable to build—costing the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are not keen on this idea.

Text: 'The Camera Never Lies

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational person and even a scientist. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence that these tiny creatures existed. He published these photos with an article where he accepted fairies as magical beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The results were undeniably beautiful. However, this simple trick challenges a basic idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and always has been able to. Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Text: Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths held a status similar to that of doctors and astrologers because they were the only ones who made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also crafted by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased, as heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used graceful wrought-iron features.

In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more open approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced looks quite traditional, with manufacturers of gates and balconies promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can hardly enter a trendy design store without seeing rusty candlesticks with decorative elements. Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmithing craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, states, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently."

Power tools have freed blacksmiths from the hard work of using a hot anvil, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld metal more easily. "In short," says Dawson, "these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork, according to Dawson. His own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a mouth-blown glass shade. "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space," he explains.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, says, "It's quite magical because it's incredibly soft when hot, but as soon as it cools, it becomes rigid and unmovable again." Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, while another resembles a Celtic cross. "I love that steel is cold and hard," she says. "It feels like it will last forever." No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are high, as long as we don't have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING'**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. I still find it strange. The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I had not planned to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won't be trying to stop myself; that wouldn't be fair." I thought it was reasonable because I enjoyed smoking. It gave me real pleasure. The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. 

What happened was that the messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge because of opposition, the idea of quitting started to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling. Could I also achieve other things? In many ways, it was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be hard without cigarettes, but it wasn't a problem at all. I had believed I wouldn't be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing things at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I am starting to think that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

Text: 'Dorothy who? The only British woman scientist to win the Nobel Prize should be well-known in her own country, says Georgina Ferry, but she is not. For the past four years, I have been asking friends and acquaintances about Dorothy Hodgkin. It’s simple: when I tell them I am writing her biography, if they respond positively, they have passed the test. Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? The fact that she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize should be enough. Anyone with the same achievement in literature would be famous. But Hodgkin, who died in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes of the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read some scientific biographies. One of Hodgkin's friends suggested a new biography of Linus Pauling. Pauling was a close friend of Hodgkin, worked in the same field, and campaigned against nuclear weapons. I went to the main bookshop in my university town, only to find that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I now realize I was naive to think Pauling would be interesting to British readers, even though he was a highly influential chemist and a Nobel Prize winner in both chemistry and peace. Even scientists have questioned the value of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull to read. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. 

Treating scientists differently from others in biographies shows the 'two cultures' mentality, the idea that there is a big gap between the arts and sciences, which still exists in the literary world. Only a few great scientists make it into the biography sections of bookshops. It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, actors, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. A leading geneticist once told me he was willing to be interviewed about his work but did not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem 'self-promoting'. This avoidance of personal stories gives a false impression of science and may discourage young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, things are changing. Contemporary scientists now often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on television. These activities may surprise some in laboratories, but they help make scientists more relatable than many academic papers do. The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and dull, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?, a funny and touching memoir of a man who was also one of the greatest theoretical physicists of the century. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws. 

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. Her major achievements included solving the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She pushed scientific techniques to new levels. However, she also had three children and a husband who was often away due to his work as a historian. Her personal life may not be directly related to her scientific work, but we can learn from how she balanced different parts of her life. There is much in her life that is interesting to everyone, but it would be unfair to say that this does not include her scientific work. 

Scientific inquiry was the passion of Hodgkin's life, as it must be for any successful scientist. Communicating this passion is the biggest challenge for a scientific biographer. Most readers do not have enough basic scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without much explanation. Understanding scientific concepts is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort. It is unfortunate that educated people, who would feel embarrassed if they did not recognize a famous literary or artistic figure, remain unaware of the rich legacy of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.'

**Text: 'Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills'**

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a 'sixth sense'. She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Farmers whose wells have dried up often seek her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she relies only on her forked hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water, minerals, and lost items underground is known as dowsing. There are many theories about how dowsing works, ranging from scientific ideas like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One of the most believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. It is thought that dowsers can sense these vibrations while standing on the ground. Some dowsers claim they can 'feel' water, while others say they can 'smell' it, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to drought, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns that have become holiday homes, where running water pipes over long distances is too expensive. There are also golf course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret typically looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She emphasizes that wells cannot be drilled where there is a risk of contamination from waste. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and if they bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, there are many minerals, so they must be careful about iron in the water. 

Another important factor is electricity to run the pump, which can be costly if the well is far from power sources. Once she considers all these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. "I hold the pendulum still and move it gently over the map. It will swing when it is above an area with water."

After identifying possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway slightly. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also dowse the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill until they reach an agreement. 

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in her practice; many anthropologists and writers have been intrigued by this mysterious ability. She describes it as an 'intuitive perception of the environment', which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this 'sixth sense', it would be hard to understand how her family could continue to succeed in their well-drilling business year after year.

**Simplified Text: 'We Changed Lives for a Day!'**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be fun to try something different! We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**A. Amanda's Story**

I had never been to a place like this before. It was dark and noisy, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and honestly, I wasn’t sure I could handle it! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. I felt so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!

By opening time at 11:30 am, there was already a line outside, and I started to feel nervous. I worried about remembering all the orders, but luckily, everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn’t get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was completely exhausted and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn’t believe it when one of the waitresses said it had been a 'quiet' day! I never realized how tiring waitressing could be. I always thought it was an easy job, but you really need to be friendly and able to handle a lot of customers at once. I’m quite shy, and I don’t think I could manage on a busy Saturday night. I wasn’t impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very happy to return to my children. It felt easy compared to waitressing!

**B. Cindy's Story**

I was nervous about being a 'mum' for a day, but I was also excited. I had been told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, rushed through the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble began. They turned the couch into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming loudly! I thought they would tire out soon, but I was wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they wore me out! After much effort, I got them to bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun began! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I realized they were just trying to come downstairs to watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never knew how tiring it could be to take care of two small children. You don’t get a moment to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's Story**

On the farm, I wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a treat! I took a long time deciding how to dress. I couldn’t show up in my farm clothes, could I? Looking at about 400 students at assembly, I hoped I blended in and that my fresh face didn’t make me stand out as a farmer. After that, I went to a math class. The children worked in small groups, using cards that were easy or hard - very different from when I was in school!

Then I helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There’s so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (which was nice!) and then a French lesson in the video room. This was fun because all the children wanted to practice their French with me, which showed how rusty I was! Finally, we went to the gym for Physical Education. I was exhausted, but the children had endless energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I’ll stick to farming!

**D. Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary’s farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep! She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which are sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers, making ice cream, and putting on labels. It was hard not to taste everything!

At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and helped a sheep that had fallen over. If sheep are left for more than 12 hours after falling, they could die, so they need to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, every day of the year! I found it quite lonely. I missed the children a lot - animals don’t talk back! The worst part of the job is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, so it’s hard to plan any time away. Rosemary will only get about three days off this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is unstable, and I wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has, at the age of 30, become a unique trumpet player in the world today. His recordings are constantly introducing new music, not only concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods but also new pieces. When you meet him, bright-eyed and attractive, he seems even younger than he is, as fresh and open in his manner as the sound of the trumpet. Recently, in one of London's top concert halls, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto, a piece he often plays, while a television feature was made about his work and growth, filmed both in London and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was just eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a trumpet. Instead of a toy, he chose a real instrument after seeking advice. The gift was a success, and the boy never stopped playing. His mother contacted the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, who agreed to give her son lessons. Bo Nilsson was a rising musician who quickly recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, one who was so passionate about the trumpet that he sought out players worldwide and was always looking for new mouthpieces. However, Hardenberger distinguishes himself from his teacher. 'The trumpet is a basic instrument,' he explains, 'so you can't create a trumpet that is acoustically perfect. There will always be flaws. Also, no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. For me, it's about understanding these flaws and building a relationship with them.' From the start, Hardenberger seemed to have a talent for finding the right balance and making that connection. Without boasting, he notes that even as a child, his unique sound was already recognizable, 'the first thing I developed.' Unlike the great British trumpet player, John Wallace, who started in brass bands and then played in orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. As a child, he looked up to the French trumpeter, Maurice Andre, another musician who avoided orchestras. He bought all of Andre's records and admired him. His parents supported his desire to practice and encouraged his ambition to pursue a career in trumpet playing. The question then became where to send him to study at 15. America, Bo Nilsson's first choice, was considered too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud confirmed Hardenberger's belief against joining an orchestra, saying that 'Playing in the orchestra is like digging in the garden.' He was realistic enough to know that he played better than others his age, but it was only after his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special ability to connect with people. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but advanced to the second. Fortunately, he already knew most pieces in that round too, but when he reached the final, he faced a concerto that had intimidated him. He did not win first prize that time, but he enjoyed the performance, realizing that even though he 'played poorly,' people were listening. Hardenberger's honest view of his work and career may seem arrogant, but that would be a misunderstanding. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what this gift of communication might be, saying, 'You risk losing it by trying to explain. The power of music lies in its ability to always move people.'

**Text:**

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insight, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a composed middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her aging father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unusual friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

**C.** This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young protagonist, Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears suddenly in the story but returns after the Second World War, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After his recent success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway approaches her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her enjoyable manipulation of both suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary aspects of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

**E.** Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical workday looks like.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7:00 am, and arrive at work by 8:00 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. There have been times when I’ve worked for ten hours straight without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about my next day’s work. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it is successful, it feels amazing, which makes up for the times it doesn’t work. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I often worry about my patients for the first few days, and I sometimes dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner who oversees everything, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only about ten to fifteen percent being actual design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. I usually have lunch at 1:00 pm for an hour, often going to a pub, but sometimes I eat sandwiches and work through lunch. It feels great when a client appreciates my designs, but it’s disappointing when a project I worked hard on gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be as late as 8:30 pm or later. I find it hard to relax when I get home, especially if I’ve had a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7:00 am, but on two or three mornings a week, I have to wake up between 4:30 am and 5:00 am for long-haul flights from Heathrow or Gatwick. At around 10:30 or 11:00 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. People often ask for my recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which allows me to plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude or unfriendly. However, most of the time, my clients are nice, and I have a good relationship with my regulars. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7:00 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most of our jobs are in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11:00 am, we take a break and go to a local café for a big breakfast. Sometimes I wish time would go slower. In summer, I may work until 10:00 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden design, I usually set up a meeting in the evening around 7:00 or 8:00 pm. We focus on using old materials and unique plants to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have very specific ideas, which can be challenging. However, it’s very rewarding to see a garden we designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can always hear the business phone ringing. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows me to be creative."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of two bridges and a retaining wall that keeps vehicles from driving into a quarry. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6:00 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2:00 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. The contractors have set meal times, so I use that time to check on the site. Since we monitor their work, it can create tension, so it’s important to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent comes up, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6:00 pm and am on call all the time."

**Text: Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am to reach the office by 7:30 am. I manage customer development programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I need to stay in touch with current card users, attract new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I oversee advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings scheduled throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to address any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes daily, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from session musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for specific artists.
