Because of this protection, we can enjoy, rather than fear, the huge clouds that hang over the valley, and we can appreciate the great power that the river has. Thanks to this safety, we feel that our home in the valley is still secure and safe.

Text: 'Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviewing—novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. That is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his team. Initially, he wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need specialized knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to discuss the artistic material Tom wanted us to cover, and there would be guests to create a friendly atmosphere. At that time, it felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. I even thought a millionaire was pretending to employ me to help me personally, reflecting my lack of self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I felt embarrassed. 

Tom's idea for a team of critics never really happened. It was a good plan, but we didn’t meet as intended, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to connect a reviewer with a specific subject area, so I chose to focus on film. Without Tom's initial support, we might not have developed the current system, where I write a detailed weekly piece, usually about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t have liked the typical film critic role, which involves reviewing every new film. That routine would quickly make me feel bored. I would soon be sitting in my seat on a Monday morning, sighing, 'What terrible film do I have to watch now?'—a sigh often heard in screening rooms worldwide. The freedom I have allows me to expand my arguments or, in a dull week, to create something interesting from little. 

But what is my role in the public eye? I believe people choose films based on the stars, the marketing, or the director. There is also loyalty to certain types of films or the opposite. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to avoid a love story because of a critic's opinion. So if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I have to be 'right' about a movie. I also don’t think there should be a specific number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. My job is to present an argument. I’m not a judge, and I wouldn’t want to be.'

Text: 'Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." A teenager who loves endurance sports is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably female. This is a chance to work with a potential Olympic champion. The partner should be very interested in distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (enjoying winter training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (a love for 100km rides is helpful). Being able to do all three sports without resting is essential. 

Triathlons are becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. They attract large crowds who are fascinated (and sometimes horrified) by athletes who swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without stopping. While it may be exciting for spectators, what drives triathletes to push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, with great academic results, give up so much for the challenges of this sport? 

Melanie Sears has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that most athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. After the 40km cycle, you have to run 10km, which feels long when you're tired. But it's great fun, and it's all worth it in the end," she says. 

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior competing. It felt so easy that I was waving at my teammates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the run." But she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would end, but I am afraid that if I stop just once, I would want to do it again." 

Such determination earns admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I've just been testing her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She gave it her all, but while most people stop when they realize they can't go further, she just kept going." 

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower in cycling. That's why I'm working very hard on it." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with £1,000 off") so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. 

However, there is a cost to her dedication. Her intense training has made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times." 

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's interesting, isn't it?

**Text: The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses the things she collects and why many people enjoy this hobby. Collecting has always fascinated me, and about one in three adults participates in it. It is a world filled with passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember this: only collect items you truly love. 

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. Attracted by their shapes and colors, these pebbles were among the first objects gathered for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been collecting for my entire life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I was sent to a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by people from the past. I was captivated by these items. 

Interestingly, I am not alone in my interest in collecting. One in three adults shares this passion. The reasons behind collecting have become a topic of great interest. Some believe it gives individuals a sense of control in their lives. For me, it is simply something I enjoy.

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like cups made from coconut shells and carved ivory beads. Another notable collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned over 4,000 paintings. However, you don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected various items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, with great determination. 

I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it until, one year, it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost when my house caught fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, looking at the remains of my furniture and collection, unsure which loss saddened me more.

I have always been intrigued by how collections change hands. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet adds value to the items traded in markets. As small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now considered valuable, as long as you kept the original boxes. (I, unfortunately, threw both the boxes and the toys away.)

**Text: My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I am in charge of creating temporary exhibitions. This involves planning, designing, and promoting the exhibition. I need to research the topic beforehand and speak with key people to understand the main themes and goals of the exhibition. I also decide which objects and images should be displayed. It is important that the public understands the ideas behind the exhibition, so I plan interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I work with engineers and electricians to ensure the final display is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., the first thing I do is check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents need to be created to help students learn the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in class, figuring out how to make the journeys. They find the most direct routes, using the correct one-way streets and turns. I step in when there is a disagreement, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. As they prepare for the test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must take a different route because the road is closed. The next student must find another route, and I will again provide a reason why they cannot go that way. This is to encourage them to think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. My job involves answering phone inquiries, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I mostly work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about ocean conservation. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the underwater life better. This experience often changes their perspectives, as it is very different from making decisions on a computer. I feel very fortunate because conservation is my passion, so I find great joy in my work. However, since I work for a charity, there is always a need for more funding, which means I am constantly looking for resources and cannot achieve everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite diverse. I ensure that our publishing program meets market needs and that we keep around 300 copies of the books we publish in stock. We maintain very high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like the representation of international borders, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a passionate team, which makes the job more enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there is too much administration to handle, which leaves less time for more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text: 'No Title'**

Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did so very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not a good experience because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it’s a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, referring to the names of the rooms we had. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when few people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles repairs and redecorating. 

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling widely, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel like we were more than just another group of hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that the others felt our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was fine. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. 

Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play for too long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From where we sat by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never finished, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. This is her second year as a chalet girl. Sarah, 24, is from West Sussex and works in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful individuals every week," she explains.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can accommodate up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower first, but she avoids sleeping. "It's not good if you do," she warns. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful - breakfast this morning was a lot of fun - but some weeks don’t go as well for various reasons."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. "We often start at Bananas, then might go to G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar," she says. However, she doesn’t stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she admits, "when you definitely don’t want to cook breakfast with a bad headache."

On Sundays, work starts earlier than usual, as breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and prepare for the next guests." If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who usually arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them," she jokes.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests who need boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory. She wore overalls and large, unattractive shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or, if they seemed serious, by giving them a short tour. 

Seymour thought Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited his factory years ago to see how gloves were made. He remembered how Marie loved to watch the workers shape and press each glove using steam-heated brass hands, which she called "pancake hands" because they looked flat and strange. 

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He was pleased to see her interest in every detail. "They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"Well, you should visit a tannery if you want to write about leather. I can help arrange that for you. They are basic places. The technology has improved, but it’s not that different from what it was hundreds of years ago. It’s tough work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; they found six-thousand-year-old tanning relics in Turkey. The first clothing was just skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject once you get into it. My father is a leather expert; you should talk to him. If you start a conversation about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers really love their trade. 

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" 

"I can't say I have." 

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 

He laughed; she made him laugh. She was innocent but eager to learn. His daughter was much taller than Rita, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. He remembered how Marie would come home from school, full of what she had learned, everything neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 

"I have an idea. We will take you through the whole process. Come on! We’re going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Text: 'Is It a Tough Job?'**

Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often travels around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss. However, there is one small issue—she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She handles some routine tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning travel, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her working behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he prefers caddying because golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, with average earnings between £25,000 and £35,000, much of which goes to travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You're not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge about the game, and try to understand the course," he explains. His accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are valuable for television commentators, golf magazines, and the players themselves.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to taste food at fine restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend, who was an editor of a Saturday Review, offering him a food column. At that time, Martin was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mainly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard at them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don't wake up at dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help."

Text: In the lumberyard by the lake, trees were turned into boards for building. There was an old two-story brick building, and outside, there were large piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles of dust covered the area down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, all the boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too. 

Still laughing, he watched as they looked down from the roof, nervous and unsure. One by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes until one of the boys said, "Let's go back up to the roof and jump down again." They weren't very excited, but they climbed back up and started jumping off in a determined way until only Michael was left. The others were down below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" 

Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly, wondering why the drop had not seemed so long the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He was trying to count to ten and then jump, but when that didn't work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. Soon, the boys began to laugh at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they started to get up and walk away, still shouting. 

"Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called out. But he stayed on the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set over the grey line of the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and fell heavily into the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. 

He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you won't come home, you might as well stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the row of smiling faces below on the sawdust pile and hearing their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change their job turn to a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. After this, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggested careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest organizations that provide career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometric tests would accurately reflect who I am. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, but I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are glad I never became a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts for help. "Losing my job was a great chance for me to step back and review my career," says Donna. "I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But in the end, I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities," she explains. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. "I decided to use my existing skills and move into a field that suited me better than insurance. I am now a Public Relations officer. I believe I would have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me understand what I truly wanted to do. I have recommended them to several friends, and they are all satisfied with the service."

Some people feel they would not have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services helped 26-year-old Juliet Greene make significant life changes. "After working at a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, which showed I was interested in sciences," she says. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which I found very helpful, as it’s easy to forget what you say. After the fourth meeting, I carefully considered the test results and decided I wanted to study geology. I plan to start a degree in it later this year. I think the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the cost. I feel much happier and more positive now."

However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says, "I reached a point in my career where I didn’t know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either required a significant pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself," she says. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Text: Fun at the Dentist's**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has tried to create a space where people feel comfortable. For example, he decided not to wear a white coat, as many people connect that with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This idea may surprise many, as most people think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome explains, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his new relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. The headsets are used during the initial check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then the headset switches to a special camera that gives the patient a visual tour of their mouth." Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit.

Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people walk in, I want them to realize with all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the most crucial factor. For instance, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a bit unusual at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it is not painful.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned there is that when you make it easier for the patient, it also makes it easier for you," he explains. He believes his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a gradual change towards less formality in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Simplified Text:**

Chocolate, which comes from South America, is now a huge global business worth millions. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, which is about eight percent of all chocolate sales for the year. Only at Christmas do people buy more chocolate. 

Although chocolate production on a large scale started in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a term that originated from a spelling mistake in the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found it tastier when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but this recipe did not reach the rest of Europe for another hundred years.

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The chocolate bar as we know it started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk solids to make milk chocolate.

At the beginning of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. Then, in 1905, Cadbury introduced the Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy image of milk from the English countryside, making it a strong competitor to rich French brands. 

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain is stable at about four bars per week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are turned into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something different.

However, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, remember the challenges faced by these farmers.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master of his craft. He still has many interests, such as paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells. "Let me know if I am boring you," he says as he shows me his work in his apartment. There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is definitely the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I have grown so fond of them. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so more people could see my art. They spoke to a gallery owner." This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of the pieces sold. His second exhibition opened at the gallery yesterday. Given the high prices of his work—around £2,000 for the ornaments—Cooke seems willing to sacrifice some space above his fireplace.

There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else in the world creates work like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

"I wish I had started this earlier," Cooke says, "because I could have created even more wonderful things. Although I still have ideas and do my best now, I am more limited physically than when I began." Nevertheless, his work is far from the typical shell items found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he explains, which has led to boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

Cooke has developed his own method and uses materials as he finds them. He repurposes cardboard from laundered shirts for his flower bases, uses a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker ("If it runs out, I don’t know what I will do!"), and washes the shells with dish soap. "I have an idea of what I want to create, and it just happens," he says about his working process. However, the attention to detail, color variations, and symmetry he achieves seem far from random.

Cooke's search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against those who accuse him of damaging the world’s beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The ones that remain are broken by the sea. I would never collect shells with living creatures inside or dive for them, but once the animals have left, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work often exceeds that of the shells themselves.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to exciting places and appearing on magazine covers, she is likely studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, that's fine," I replied. I had been trying to convince myself that the negative things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she thought going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be rushing and in a bad mood, refusing to answer my questions. 

However, when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, accompanied by her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, tall, and pretty girl. Kira explained that all models under 16 must bring an adult with them to work, and her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was just a normal mum.

Kira seems a bit confused by her sudden fame, which is understandable since it was unexpected. It was her older sister who suggested she enter the modeling competition. "She saw the competition and said I should join," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When she received the call saying she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to continue, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Kira now finds it challenging to manage her two separate lives. Her friends and teachers have gotten used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, some unkind people at her school make rude comments about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This must be difficult for Kira to handle, as she is not self-important at all. She explains, "They think that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that has changed is that I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call at any time to tell her she is needed for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll join them because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are understanding. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even take their school-leaving exams. As I finish the interview with this girl who seems to have it all, I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the beauty that is likely to take her to the top. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Text: Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool.

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the most promising land to explore. Since they first cleared the area and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They have dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. After spending their savings on this dream, they need to convince an investor to put £50,000 into the project to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, although we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. "If they are right, it would bring more visitors here," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if they find gold, I hope millions of people don’t come and disturb the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, where they cannot stand up or move, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey," she says.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They traveled five days west of the Canary Islands to a site with many underwater volcanoes, where black smoke is released. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers,'" she explains. This term refers to underwater volcanoes that release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel recalls a frightening experience during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. "There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible—we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD, and when I finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

Text: 'I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I said as I stepped onto home ground. I repeated this the following year and the next. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Ordinary beds feel different once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, rocked into a deep sleep. Carrying all your belongings in a rucksack leads to a simple way of traveling and encourages wastefulness, like burning socks that have become too dirty and getting rid of books after reading them. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be set aside along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to feel this freedom is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize the full potential of this train ticket, thinking it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of continuous travel was too tempting, as there was always one more country to visit, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like most other Inter-Railers, and in planning our own schedule, we focused only on the most accessible sights. This was our chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that, in many places, all I wanted to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and enjoy ourselves. In this, we were like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city you arrive in never existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you experience it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be so dull. While the train trip may not let you discover new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail offers the best chance to appreciate this, though it didn’t happen for us right away.'

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in unsuitable clothes. Although airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is a common issue that regular travelers will eventually face. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially when your journey involves one or more flight changes.

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also extended to allow for luggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which can disrupt the baggage system. Human error or accidents, such as a destination label being torn off, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large transfer airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 

For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom transferred between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The risk of losing luggage during plane changes is higher at certain airports. The United States also faces issues; Miami airport is known for losing luggage when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America.

To reduce the chance of losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a peaceful atmosphere, just like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, so striking that you can almost feel its presence. It disappears in an instant, but the image stays in your mind, its impact greater than its small size.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep feelings for this little bird are shown by his uncertainty about what exactly attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess that turned into a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Despite the many shades of blue in their feathers, kingfishers do not have blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light and reflects blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. The combination of their colors and the fact that, although they are shy, they can be observed easily from a distance makes them fascinating. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a major part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream rich with kingfishers. Unfortunately, school limited his time with the birds, and he missed classes, calling himself an "academic failure." But his interest in this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and gradually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I’m drawn to the simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks of the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still captivate him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever show.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later asked to help with another opera the next season. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous. I have always felt confident standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since that first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several more projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after unsuccessful attempts in two others. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many performance opportunities and a chance to work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, Constantine struggles with being known only for the competition: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are inviting me back. If that doesn't happen, my career could suffer."

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial center until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from much larger conductors, which makes a big difference." Kani appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says, "Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me." This career choice is not so strange; he started as a resident musician with an opera house and worked with talented conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I did my best to achieve the performance I wanted. Fortunately, people respect my skills as a musician. I benefit from all my experiences, both in musical style and performance. Now, I will accept any opportunity to discover what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor during one of his productions and told his agent about Wayne Marshall. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a challenging start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and aimed for the best result. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need guidance from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express what I want. If people see you’re worried, it gets worse. I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are thinking about taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere, and the scenery was not very impressive. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could see easily! The older children liked the ferris wheel and enjoyed driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still more to explore. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also a lot of fun for younger children. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they realized they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not too boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am not very brave, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave enough. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it a little boring, but they were the right age and enjoyed it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we definitely felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out in the park, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Text: Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. "My customers are friends," says Christine Hogan, who runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were young, and I wanted a job I could do from home. I had worked with computers before marriage, so my husband suggested I start a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. I was careful and always informed the bank manager if I might overspend. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evenings if I choose. My business has stayed small, and we rarely deliver work; customers from the area usually come to pick it up."

B. "I enjoy being independent," says Maggy Sasanow, who designs greeting cards from home. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where such jobs were not available. So, I decided to start my own business and now create a range of 50 greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. My business relies entirely on word of mouth; I don’t advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I miss sharing ideas with others, but overall, the benefits outweigh the drawbacks."

C. "It has been challenging at times," says Delia Turner, who runs a curtain-making business that has experienced ups and downs. "I started my business eight years ago when this type of work was growing. In two years, my earnings increased from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to manage six full-time curtain-makers, but I had to let them go due to the economic decline, which was hard because finding other jobs in this area is not easy. Now, I am back to making curtains at home with my husband’s help and using women who work from their homes. I must be ready to lower my prices when needed and explore new opportunities."

D. Tessa Strickland manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons: it was cheaper than London, and I love the countryside. I enjoy being able to work when I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at unusual hours. The downside is that I need discipline to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. I had all my professional experience in London, so I felt very isolated at first."

E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home. I am very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with high-quality flour and eggs. Soon, I received requests from friends and family, and I started sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where everything is made; we have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don’t bake anymore, as I manage the business side. My biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, which has been tough because we didn’t have a lot of money to start with."

**Text: Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. Matthew Rye reports.

It is not uncommon to find families of musicians, but it is rare to find one that includes both music creators and an instrument maker. When John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they were surprised by the high prices. John says, "We looked at different shops, and it was clear it would be very expensive. So, I thought about making one myself. I found out that the Welsh School of Instrument Making was nearby, and I attended evening classes once a week for about three years."

Paul, now 28, adds, "After trying to make violins and violas a few times, he made his first cello. It turned out really well. He made me another one later, which I used until a few months ago." John has since retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a great achievement for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul remembers, "I started with the piano as soon as I could reach the keys. But soon, I was drawn to the cello. My parents wanted me to play the violin because Dad played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. I tried it for about six weeks but didn’t enjoy it. I was inspired by the cellist in Dad's group, who I thought was really cool when I was six or seven. He offered to give me lessons, and that’s how it all began. Later, they wanted Huw to play the violin too, but he wasn’t interested."

Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were supportive but not pushy. I think I would have struggled if they had forced me. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul's success, I found it motivating." Huw is now starting to make a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

John's cello has helped Paul achieve great things. With it, Paul won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20 years old, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, a role he held while still using his father's instrument until last year. Now, he has a Francesco Rugeri cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul says, "Dad hasn’t said anything about me moving on, but he recently played both cellos and admitted that my new one is quite nice! The only thing Dad's cello might gain over time is the ability to project sound in large concert halls. It will get richer with age, just like my Rugeri, which is already 304 years old."

Soon, Paul will perform on television as the soloist in Elgar's Cello Concerto, which is part of a new series called Masterworks. He says, "The history of the performance doesn’t change how I play it. I will always do it my way." However, Paul won’t be able to watch himself on TV because he is performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw also has a performance, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will need to be organized and energetic to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills because they interact with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies regularly. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the position of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. 

He says, "It helps that I still farm with my parents, so I can relate to farmers and understand their issues. They can't fool me!" His farming background also prepares him for the physical demands of the job, such as building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers, "When I was young, I used to pick flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and find old birds' nests. Recently, I wondered where I could find those flowers and nests now. It has become clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice."

Gareth notes that when he started, farmers and conservationists were often in conflict, each wanting things done their way. Now, they are communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. "We're at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," he says. 

Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to ensure tasks are completed efficiently and with minimal fuss. What I enjoy most is seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork."

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. However, he admits, "I dislike the attitude of some visitors. They come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to those people can be frustrating!" But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. 

If you have plenty of common sense and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just don't expect a position to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, typical for the weeks before the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket car park. 

"Don't you get strange looks?" I asked her. "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else," she replied. "I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it." 

"My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships," Kendra said. "I follow a strict schedule to be as fit as possible." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the biggest yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People expect us to start the tournament with a strong game." 

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra notes that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it." 

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard not to win," Kendra said. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We are all friendlier after the game." 

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explained. "As captain, I believe it is important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team." 

"From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned," she said. "I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may very well have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their gift. Some parents may not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who are musically talented, and those whose abilities are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established relatively recently. These schools aim to create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to develop their skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music-related activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their day is filled with a limited academic program that focuses on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with smaller class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. One major issue is the cost; fees for boarding students range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. Each school tries to help parents of exceptionally gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, all specialist schools monitor their students closely and provide support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education. Children who are also academically gifted may thrive in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a normal school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as orchestral and chamber music experiences.
