However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, and the large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west show a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures. This is largely thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also inherited the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. However, she sometimes paints a group of plants in their natural setting. More often, she picks the flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of the flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they each change into different shapes. They open up and look amazing. When you first put them in a vase, they seem dull, but they change all the time with twists and turns."

Susan has always been interested in plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really into gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers. I thought they looked like the fake ones sold in some flower shops—only wildflowers seemed real to me. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliff tops."

Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they did in China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a loving aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but despite the need to paint, she knows that to stay connected with her subjects, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. This is her second year as a chalet girl. Sarah, 24, is from West Sussex and works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful guests every week," she explains.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she says. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week wonderful. Breakfast this morning was great fun, but some weeks are not as good for various reasons."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. "We often start at Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar," she shares. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you really don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."

On Sundays, work starts earlier, as breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for the next guests." If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them," she jokes.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps any guests who need ski boots or equipment and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my outfit for Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around when I could be quietly spending time with an animal. Some members of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job is not very pressurized. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I found it funny to think that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I stroked one of the elephants, I thought Mandie would probably be packing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a wonderful day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening program Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My idea of gardening did not include hard physical work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to quit my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would feel faint doing some tasks, but I surprised myself by managing well. The friendship among the nurses was great, and it felt very different from my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important compared to nursing. My day at the hospital was not pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, it is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I ever saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we had to take the Desert Express. The schedule was unpredictable; we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days to leave if he knew people were still coming. When the train finally arrived, there was a rush of people climbing into and onto the carriages—some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are young, but that’s not true for me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had carefully maintained. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Are you trying to get published? If you want to know where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Can you tell me who to send it to?" One of the first things they need to understand is that they should research their markets and learn about publishers while also improving their writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. No matter what type of writing you do, you need to know the markets you are targeting. There are several ways to do this, but the best way is to read as much as you can about relevant topics. Use your local library and visit local bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. This knowledge needs to be updated regularly because new publications are always appearing—editors change jobs, and magazines change focus. Publishers are always looking for new talent, so as writers, we must give them what they want. 

At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. For example, if you think you would like to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories, as this is a limited market today. Get as many recent copies as you can and learn about the types of stories they are buying, paying attention to who their readers are. These readers will have different expectations, and the editor wants to meet their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it is likely that the work is not yet ready for publication. I try to give honest feedback while remaining positive. The issue is that many new writers are too eager to submit their work, often before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This almost never happens. When you read about someone’s success, you often find that they have been in the publishing or journalism field for years before achieving that success. 

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will improve both your fluency and confidence. Don’t discard any of your work—focus on improving it instead. I also recommend not sharing your work with others, especially in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby. If you can’t find one, consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

**Text: No Title**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I had expected. The usual clean and bright feeling of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags all over the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers one by one. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn’t mind talking to her. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, northbound, yes," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" 

"No, New York, but I'll be..." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. "Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said, "Wilmington," he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn’t; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed now. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She lowered her book. She looked about thirty or thirty-five—older than me. A schoolteacher type. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Then could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my left wrist (even though I didn’t own a watch). I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They were announcing my train now. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets on leashes. 

Next, I heard the man talking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries afterward, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn’t know what to do." The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where he was going with this. 

"So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would get someone to bring her passport." I thought this was a strange story. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? 

"Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

The restaurant owner John Moore talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. He believes everyone has a chance in life. His son Gary had a chance to cook, and John had a chance to run a restaurant. When he learned about the opportunity, he quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans. Starting this business reminded him of his childhood. He remembers how his mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad being left alone. Because of this, he wanted to make time for family. His wife took care of the children and managed the accounts while he ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This has helped their children, Gary and Joe, become very confident. From a young age, they would talk to regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs, and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined and would wake up even before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and it was nice to see Gary doing his part. Although he wasn't very good at school, he excelled in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes was even in charge. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would pursue a career in catering because of his talent.

When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend who owned a restaurant. Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." He also told Gary that if he wanted to achieve something, he needed to do it by age 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he and the other new students, who were usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He was helping others by the end of the day. No one can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become, and John is very proud of him. He has always told Gary that if you want something, you must work hard for it because no one gives you anything. Gary has recognized the opportunity he was given and has taken full advantage of it. John knows that as children grow up, they may only remember a small part of what parents say, but he is happy that Gary seems to have listened at times.

**Text:**

Finding a good flat in Dublin at an affordable price was very difficult. The best way to find one was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often helped. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts to inform you about available rooms. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For her, Dublin felt like a big unknown. She felt nervous when she took the train to work there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave. Who would stay in a small town? That’s all she had heard for years. Her friends wanted to escape, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates had moved to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be good for her to stay permanently in the hostel run by nuns, believing she would be safe there. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm, as they were often cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying a whole week in a hostel. However, Jo was unaware that they were still thinking about her as she responded to an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her workplace and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive!

There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary—just a red-brick terraced house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and a cheerful girl with a college scarf, who looked like a rejected applicant, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she told Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt."

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up the stairs. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"Do? She didn’t have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, was a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 

"I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa mentioned they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one had "Nessa," one had "Pauline," and the last one had "Other" written on it. "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are among the most intelligent animals, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by television. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by law and cared for in marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are often seen in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once frequently seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, including the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, such as skin injuries.

The complex behavior of dolphins makes it hard to understand why their numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is greatly reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also endangers porpoises and dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they often die after being caught in these nets.

Pollution in the sea can also harm dolphins. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies because they are fat-soluble. Female dolphins produce milk that contains these toxins, which can poison their young. There is already one recorded case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s contaminated milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**Getting Fit**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to. 

Exercise improves your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It increases muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also helps prevent muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. Additionally, exercise can improve specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits before, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can improve your sleep. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you’re not convinced yet, just think about it: exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to overdo it, as training too hard can lead to injuries. Start slowly, and if you’re unsure, talk to your doctor about what’s best for you.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. If you have poor posture, it can make you look and feel less energetic and can lead to minor health issues. To improve your posture, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head upward. This can help you lift your chest for better breathing and make your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It increases flexibility and helps you move easily, which can prevent injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Your exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their comfortable homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to several unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their partnership has produced some of television's best wildlife films, including a well-received film about leopards. While this film about one of Africa's shyest cats was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time tracking the equally shy jackal. 

This is common in television partnerships. Traveling filmmakers have been exploring the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman about their partnership while he was having a rare reunion with other people at a safari lodge. "We do have occasional arguments, but we tend to resolve them quickly," he says about working with Amanda. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and one reason they get along well is that they both view the animals similarly. "When we are on the move, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we are working from a more fixed camp, so we prepare tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so cooking can sometimes be stressful," says Newman. 

It can be a tough life, but the advantage of being in such remote areas is that they can get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman recalls filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often wander off. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions in the pride, and eventually, she included their vehicle in her greetings. 

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they began filming Arctic foxes together. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a strong working relationship from the beginning," says Newman, "because it was clear we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the atmosphere, brings to life the true spirit of the place and its animals, and touches people's hearts. I believe that evoking an emotional response is much more powerful than just appealing to logic."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to achieve maximum fitness. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest yet, with 27 nations participating. "We'll have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People expect us to start the tournament with a strong game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra notes that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only get one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard just to lose," Kendra says. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We are all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It’s essential that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes it’s important to have a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the rest of the team."

Kendra says, "From the very beginning, my netball career has been carefully planned." She decided some time ago that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she will probably have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters are with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

"Inside," she says, "the space is so small that I can reach out and touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, which means we can't stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting samples of rock and water, and then three hours to return to the surface."

"If something goes wrong and you need to get to the top quickly, you can press a panic button. The outside drops away, and a small escape vessel is released, which quickly rises to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

"I didn't know how I would react the first time I climbed into the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing how I would react in such a small space." 

Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site that was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys releasing black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a multi-national program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When she is not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I was scared was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible—we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how fast or slow we speak, as well as our voice tone and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believed being on time was very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who worked at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People often think that what’s inside matters most, but in an interview, you should try to present yourself in the best way possible." However, many people overlook the importance of having a professional appearance.

For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not even get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed she did a great job and that her appearance should not matter.

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview, leading to an immediate job offer. She was very happy but reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once her boss sensed her excitement, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can greatly affect the success of an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can provide information about the company’s activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can create a positive impression and show your interest in the company. Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and highlight key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer exciting; it became a grind - no one was having fun anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. I didn’t receive a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed for me: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very helpful. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a leap into the unknown. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. It meant leaving our friends, but we’ve been lucky; our friendships have survived the distance, and many of them visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
After working for five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. "My job as a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even more hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. Since it’s a fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am completely responsible for the product. If I do a poor job, I am the one who takes the blame. Of course, you care when working for a company, but when your name is on the promotional material, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in financial markets since I was 22, setting up deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left voluntarily and traveled for a year. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I was offered part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That is the best part."

**Text: 'Dedicated to Their Sports'**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training can be expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It’s enjoyable because there are excellent athletics facilities and a lively nightlife. However, I need to be very disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to decline. I wish I didn’t have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to qualify for the next Olympics—that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I do enjoy sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it is worth it because without this dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice getaway. The sacrifices are worthwhile because winning that championship allowed me to host a surfing series on TV. I guess I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When five guys are on a boat together, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and always celebrate our wins in style. Some say we act a bit childishly when we celebrate, but we don’t seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than in our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to return home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can’t live and breathe the sport all the time—it’s not healthy. I am known in the sailing world, but I can count on one hand how many times I’ve been recognized in public. I wouldn’t want to be a celebrity. I do receive many nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I make sure to reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the support of the crowd. At my last tournament, things got a bit hectic with fans crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping. However, it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I received too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that’s part of why we broke up. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn’t bother me too much, though. I’m focused on my game now and will catch up on other aspects of life after I retire, which happens relatively early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It feels impossible."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when compared to attractive advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb points out, "The main goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels uneasy about how she handles their shopping requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, while we fill our trolley with cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers, making up for any loss in sales.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created after extensive research into what customers want and nearly two years of work converting four large 18th-century houses. This approach allowed for the installation of advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to keep track of guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special treatment for returning clients. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a significant part of the hotel's clientele, making up to 65% of its business. To cater to their needs, the hotel has brought traditional business center services into individual rooms. Each room is equipped with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities.

Technology evolves quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future upgrades by laying extra cables. They rent televisions instead of buying them, allowing for easy replacement with newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated as needed. Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are spacious, well-furnished, and inviting.

The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden. As with all luxury hotels, the food must be exceptional. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant on-site is a great advantage without financial risks. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**Text: Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I think excitement gives me energy. I need to be challenged and learn new things. Right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing, which is very energizing. If I'm bored, I feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, boosts my energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not a chore for me. When I get enough sleep, I feel great. I know exercise gives me energy, but sometimes it's hard to find the motivation. I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don't eat perfectly for energy; I think my natural enthusiasm helps. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people energizes me. I enjoy taking photos and writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and being positive. Working with kids is great because they are full of energy. Smiling at others can create a positive feeling. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking and drinking, but I don't have a strict exercise routine. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "I love creating gardens from wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also motivates me. I enjoy exploring nature, even if it means sneaking onto private land."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "It's important to have an interest in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don't enjoy drains my energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I found them exhausting. You should focus your energy on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. Among the upper classes in Scandinavia, skating was considered an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish and reserved, but at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style that made skating very popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are very important, and speed comes with practice. The way you position your body is crucial for balance. Keeping your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed helps you maintain your center of weight, leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is essential in skating, more than in many other sports. 

To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outward. As you push forward with your back foot, make a small movement with the other foot. If you can keep this up, you can gradually increase the length of your movements as you gain experience. Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, stay relaxed to reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.

Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can practice different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance, so you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.

If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, it is important to follow a regular exercise program. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates an excellent program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Bills**

If there's one thing that can make you cry with joy, it's seeing a talented child receive a medal. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "Right now, the training is very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off, or you get stiff."

B. **Annika's Mother**  
"From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen some parents push their children, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy, and she has to want it herself. People often say we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence through her success."

C. **Sarah Stokes, 12**  
Sarah started show-jumping at age ten and has won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents love show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun of show-jumping. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I’m determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I’m not doing it for them. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's Mother**  
"From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age one, I knew she had found her passion. When she was five, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living quarters of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is completely happy on a horse and knows what she’s doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is an amazing feeling."

E. **Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being arrogant; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like feeling embarrassed."

F. **Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first game when she was five. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age six, she was beating adults. Of course, I’m happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to discourage her because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" The teacher had a point because Chris, at fourteen, was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More and more tall people are being born. Interestingly, this does not mean we are creating a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how we were as cavemen. We are losing the effects of generations of poor diet, which is having a big impact. "We are only now beginning to reach our true potential," says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals (a lifestyle still seen in some remaining tribes of hunter-gatherers). One study found that they ate from 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which had serious consequences. Most of the planet's green areas have been taken over by farmers, leading to just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - providing more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has harmed human health and development. Over the centuries, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when they started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Some anthropologists argue that corn was not a blessing but a public health disaster.

Despite this, agriculture spread because a piece of farmed land could support ten times more people than those living as hunter-gatherers. The fact that many people relying on this system are poorly nourished has only recently been addressed, even in wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it comes with its own challenges. Heights may have increased, but the world has not fully adapted. The standard bed length has remained at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, while clothing manufacturers are constantly updating their products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel from the University, it could be as high as 193 cm, and we might reach it sometime this century. However, scientists add an important note. While individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller as an adaptation to the cold. (Larger, round bodies are better at keeping heat.) Since the climate warmed, we seem to have become slightly thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. As the planet continues to warm, we may shrink even more. In other words, the growth of humans could be affected by global warming.

**Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman explored this question. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of television, but many of us find them mysterious. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are often seen as the least important type of audience. Some people in television even look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home don’t understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through hours of boredom just to watch what they can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on television. I didn’t believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said, “I came for a chance to be on TV.” Another idea is that people are curious about what happens behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was simply, “A friend gave me a ticket.”

Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it’s like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you respond accordingly. This may be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, “We believe a good show doesn’t need these signs.”

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is “more exciting,” while Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live television. “Last year, I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot.” What I missed was seeing the live actors; I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from my seat, so I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Simplified Text:**

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes that are untouched by people. I find the human element important. This is also true when I travel abroad. I am attracted to charming villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England, and on Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape from school. I loved exploring the bare hilltops, the sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. In a way, that was my first attempt at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn’t cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our small train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers see people in their homes, making tea, washing dishes, or setting up a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people’s lives. It’s the everyday nature of the landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This makes me look more closely, searching for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and filled with rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to enjoy the beauty of the sea. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there and not many visitors either. It’s a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and since then, I have visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is the place of my dreams. It is a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, the wind, and the birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are 'animal people' who love being around all kinds of creatures. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked excitedly. I agreed, but only for one night. We had prepared a special tank for such visitors, allowing us to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly put a pot on to boil when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The chaos involved Domino the cat and Bianca, the white mouse I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the flailing arms of the children.

In the midst of the confusion, I tripped and fell. As I considered how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake had escaped. It was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat were jumping around in a wild, noisy mess. The dog was barking loudly, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over.

I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet, and surprisingly unharmed mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, that same mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged by my success with the cat, I examined the snake for any weak spots, but it had none. I ended up sitting on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without a flute. Gradually, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked suspicious. 

I slowly slid my hands under the snake and lifted it to a kneeling position, then stood up and walked to the end of the garden. I pointed the snake towards a tree, hoping it would find a good place to live. When I finally let go of its head, expecting it to bite me, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter.

As dusk fell, my four children, the snake, and I stood together. DJ, my oldest, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." I had the children gather at the snake's tail and gently encourage it to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, three-year-old Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Drop me a line! In our fast-paced world of phones, faxes, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, receiving a letter brings a unique joy that no other form of communication can match. There is excitement when a letter arrives, pleasure in seeing who it is from, and enjoyment in reading its contents. Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to train as a doctor in London, I wrote to my parents once a week, and they wrote back. Occasionally, my father would write, and his long, funny letters were always a joy to receive. Most letters from home shared everyday events about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but it is the letters I remember most. I also received letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I often attracted people who had to work or study away, and we kept in touch through letters. Instead of harming our relationships, letter writing seemed to strengthen them. I found it easier to express myself in writing than in conversation. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but having a year’s worth of news is even better! It’s even more exciting when it comes in an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. I receive letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There’s also a lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn’t started talking in a restaurant on the way home from a holiday, if my husband hadn’t taken her photo, and if I hadn’t asked for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a wonderful friendship. Now, we have regular correspondence. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success came this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a friendship could last so long. The local press even thought it was newsworthy enough to report on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain is thought to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are about 4,000 years old. These include images of cows, fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being harmed by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and damages the artwork. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer," he explains. "The drawings are already polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He warns that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees with de Lumley's strict plan. He says, "While it is the most effective, it will also cause protests from local residents." He adds that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything possible to protect it.

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "De Lumley's idea isn't ideal. Our department believes the best solution is to let people visit, but the area is so large that it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage. I would prefer that everyone could see it, but the main problem is money. We do not have enough funds to hire enough guards. We may need to consider charging a fee, as there seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—tourists can now avoid the long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she says. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for future generations."

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn to make their own choices. It feels impossible."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when compared to attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It’s good for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products.
