Text: 'Line Dancing

Many people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. In nearly every town, you can find clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to meet new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino's great body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live for up to 50 years.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few elderly men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was growing. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people preferred to stay at home.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of men to catch thieves. They were similar to police officers and were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown larger and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was established with 3,000 officers. Most of the men patrolled on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are well paid, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Would you like to join a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The cost of the trip is £25. It gets very cold at night, so please bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to come, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people travel to Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with actors and artists from around the world. They come to Edinburgh for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are alive with music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting in the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists visit the Festival to watch new films and plays and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be challenging, so consider booking your hotel now!'

**ICE-FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim beneath the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. 

"You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top," he says. "Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Then, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. You put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!"

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm having a tough week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he has a summer job. We can't go camping together now. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can. Greg'

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's Museum is a well-known attraction for tourists in London. Visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him in this work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, and only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early models looked very different from modern bicycles. Over time, as bicycles became less expensive, more people started to buy them. Many began using bicycles for commuting and leisure activities. 

Today, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to ride bicycles to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went directly to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers would give a new brush filled with paint to each elephant and take the old one away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they no longer work there, but the smartest of these animals live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These lions often work together to hunt for food. They typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats have excellent eyesight, which helps them catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I regret to inform you that I can no longer attend your class because I must return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents will prepare a large meal for the guests, and there will be much work to do in the kitchen. I am sorry to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please send my regards to the other students. Thank you once again. Best wishes, Soraya'

Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you! How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a nice Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please try to be on time!

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I am excited because last month I started a new job in the city center. I work at a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I begin work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up quite early! I enjoy this job because I meet people from many different countries. I like sharing information about our city with them. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it? Best, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometres per hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has won many competitions in this sport. We spoke to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked her why she started. "I've always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months." 

We also asked her about practice. "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains; it's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best for me." 

Finally, we asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes to stay dry because, at first, you will fall a lot!"'

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are several routes to the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to complete and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the summit succeed. This is often due to sudden changes in the weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, climbers encounter ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

Text: 'Otters

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were so polluted that many fish and insects died, leaving otters without food. However, today there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, 

I am happy that you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but I now live in England. Please write to me and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you could send me? I am sending you a few photos of my family. I will send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon. 

Tom'

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a great teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. Carlos 

Dear Carlos, 

Hotels in the center are costly, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria, and she said you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! That will be fine with you, right?

Text: 'Buildings

People have always created buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful things. Many people work together on a building project. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to show their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. 

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from all sides, not just the top. Another well-known roof is on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The issue is that I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short for me now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large image of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. No one knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the image. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always smiled and laughed, which made people in her hometown love her. Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with a very good time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop competing because he injured his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it is not enjoyable for Mike when Gail runs ahead of him and he cannot keep up. 

Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes a break from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Text: Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and a year later, he began playing the piano. He gave his first concert at six years old. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef has always loved music, but he is also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he hopes to write his own music.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. "My ten grandchildren don’t live nearby, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad." This way, Bill has learned what young children want to read. 

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His fifth book is his favorite: *The Sheepdog*, which is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest technology to make it seem like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn’t change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often nicer than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it showed a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards included images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important people. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

Text: 'Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaurs died about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were over 5,000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was smaller but much stronger. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run quickly because of its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS The bear can be a dangerous animal. An adult bear is very strong and can kill a person. Bears are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they find food using their sense of smell. There are seven types of bear: The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bear: One lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish-brown. Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Not many pandas live in the wild today because it is hard for them to find food.'

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually live in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat a variety of things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they also hunt large animals or even people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, and they all have very sharp teeth. Although they often lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Crocodiles are typically about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. They have long lifespans; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Airplanes changed significantly over the next thirty years. Then, in the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, making the trip from London to New York just four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is located in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I'm enjoying my holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful, and we don't want to go home! See you at the end of September. Sue'
